title: The use of swearing
body:
I wrote this thread because of how swearing is oftenly used in abundance on the boards but also because I think that swearing has an important place in this community and mods must be careful when censoring it. So I thought people might be interested in some insights (this thread does not nearly cover all there is to say, but I hope that what I included will be helpful for some people).

Swearing is something that carries a lot of meaning and is an important tool for expressing oneself. Like most tools however, some boundaries need to be respected so that this tool doesn't destroy more than it builds.

One of the most important uses of swearing is to express emotion. It is actually believed that people who swear sometimes are considered more trustworthy and likeable than people who don't swear. 

That has several reasons. People who swear give a strong statement as to where their moral inclinations lie and also show that things can affect them enough to inspire an emotional response. This creates a little moment of intimacy where a spectator/ reader gets to know the swearing person a bit better. It is also useful for getting the reader to feel something about a topic as well.

It simply serves as a very honest expression of emotion.

This is also a bit problematic. While a bit emotion can get people to sympathize with you, improper use of swearing can feel like too much emotion for readers. Especially in an anonymous online environment, people generally don't want to be burdened by the negative emotions of someone else.

Another problem is that emotion and rationality often are considered to be opposites. This is especially of importance when one tries to discuss something. Swearing can undermine how rational or well thought out your opinion/thread sounds. This means that if you actually care about getting a discussion going (instead of just to vent), you must chose wisely how and whether you want to swear. There are actually very fine lines here, but a general rule of thumb is that swearing works better for this purpose if it is kept basic.

For example:

“For f.ucks sake, these Vayne buffs are bad“.

vs

“These Vayne buffs are f.ucking r.etarded“.

Both phrases show how the author feels but the second goes a step further by making a very illogical connection between “buffs“ and “r.etarded“. While this may make sense emotionally, logic dictates that such a connection is impossible which makes the author come across as unreasonable. Being believed to be unreasonable is the death of most discussions.

It is not uncommon for people to think that the author must have been aware of the relationship between swearing and being considered rational. So swearing despite this knowledge can be seen as not caring about having a discussion in the first place. This is why swearing better works if it's used sparingly and with a specific purpose in mind.

Something which derives from this, is that excessive swearing works better on people who already agree with you (since they are share a similar emotional mindset), while people who disagree or have no opinion will feel rather inclined to distance themselves from you. This is not what you want for a discussion.

Another important aspect of swearing is that in general, it is considered offensive and forbidden. This matters in multiple ways. Knowing that it might offend people and still using it, is a powerful sign of disrespect. This can be averted to an extent though by the use of untargeted swear words.The use of f.uck for example is open and non descriptive for any groups.The use of b.itch or the n-word however indirectly targets specific groups, even if they were meant to describe for example the vayne buffs.

However, the offensive and taboo character can also be used as powerful tools to underline your point. Swearing is in many cultures akin to breaking the rules, if you do it anyways and you do it smartly, you express the notion that you think that your opinion was worth breaking the rules for. Which is a strong and clear signal to any reader.

One additional point that leads to awkward situations sometimes is that swearing can be used amicably for teasing or as a joke. This expresses very strongly that you like someone or something. However, swearing in jest is mostly done between friends. Outside that condition it will most likely not be well received and should be avoided in the first place.

I hope some of this was useful to you and if there is enough demand I might expand about the topic some more.

Let me know what your own thoughts are about the matter!

Signed by: 
a passionate swearer

{{champion:267}} I fucking love a good swear.

Your post highlights the difficulties with it however, considering it can make people pay less attention to what you are saying or put less stock in your opinion in general.

We wont moderate swearing outside of excessiveness (ie a post spamming fuck nonstop, graphic use of sexual language etc) or harassing, offensive, pejorative or hateful language directed at others on the general subboards. Some sub-boards, such as Gameplay+ might be moderated a bit more harshly for overall tone of the post however.

I don't remember where I read it but the use of swearing oftentimes can indicate a higher than average intelligence level of the swearer :^)

What the hell does "pejorative" mean? Mods always use that word whenever they remove something from a post and usually get mass downvoted for it.
Just curious.

Pejorative is both a basket term for words and phrases that are insulting, offensive or derogatory and for words and phrases that are _made_ insulting, offensive or derogatory by the context of the usage (_You're such a fucking spoon_). We tend to use it over those terms because it's more general.

> [{quoted}](name=Raymønd Åmantius,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=vGRG3aGQ,comment-id=00000002,timestamp=2018-12-17T16:45:54.056+0000)
>
> What the hell does "pejorative" mean? Mods always use that word whenever they remove something from a post and usually get mass downvoted for it.
> Just curious.

I think it is safe to assume that an important difference between general swearing and pejorative language is that pejorative language often specifically targets people, groups or things and is thus more used to hurt or look down on people.

This can be done directly by insulting someone or indirectly by using a term which describes a group with a very negative connotation. An example for the latter would be: "These Vayne buffs are a.utistic." While you don't directly insult anyone, you use a term which describes actual people negatively and thus have a higher chance of being perceived as hurtful. 

Needless to say I think the mods also use the term because it gives some breathing room for interpretation, which gives them some flexibility to adapt to changing habits when it comes to the use of pejorative language.

The "reason" is that mobile browsers are **_SHIT_**. First, mobile devices have tiny screens, often with ridiculously high resolution, making sizing a hassle right off the bat. Then you'll be making your pretty little page with a whopping few dozen fucking lines of HTML and CSS, and someone tries it on their iPad and says it doesn't work and you look into it and find that e.g. "position: fixed;" ISN'T SUPPORTED, and the workarounds don't work, and you end up just saying "I hate telephones" and slapping the page's calculated result into an alert() for devices with a touchscreen.

And you're checking for a touchscreen because there's no correct way to detect mobile devices. You either check for touch points (which is concise, but doesn't account for the niche cases of a desktop machine with a touchscreen) or you sniff the userAgent (which is a terrible, terrible way to do it). But of course the way that a mobile browser implements "use desktop site" is by _spoofing the userAgent_, or possibly inspecting the device's DPI maybe, if it feels like it, who knows, so if you're not detecting mobile in a horrible way, there'll be no way for, say, someone on a Surface to request the _good_ version of your webpage.

And that, boys and girls, is why "there's an app for that." Remember when the World Wide Web was all the rage? You could even check your email in a browser, without installing Eudora (remember that?) or Thunderbird. But now mobile is popular, and mobile browsers are garbage, so we're back to installing dozens of standalone programs for the simplest shit.

I love the irony in this, but I assume you didn't read my post.

I hear this argument a lot where people pretend that it is not their job to express their thoughts in a way that is palatable (within reason of course) for people.

Yet they are simply ignorant to the fact that the way you express yourself has measurable effects on how you are perceived. Perception is rarely a good argument, but there is a probability calculation here where certain traits are linked with things like 'state of mind', 'subjectiveness' and 'general knowledge' about a matter. This is especially true for an online environment. So if you are invested in getting your point across instead of just screaming in a room, you better put some thought in the words you use. 
This is a simple fact.

Think about it like this. When you swear and curse and damn the world in your post, you express strong emotional attachment to your words/point. This is a very human thing to do. Yet somehow the readers are supposed t be detached and only read what is essential in your post? I don't fucking think so.

> Yet somehow the readers are supposed t be detached and only read what is essential in your post? I don't fucking think so.

Yes the reader makes that choice and the reader always decides whether a post is worth a serious answer or not.

I can differentiate between swearing + good points and swearing + a bunch of nonsense and on top of that I decide whether I want to address a point or just start trolling.

If you don't understand that you are probably very easy to manipulate on an emotional level.

But trash wrapped in nice words is still trash for me and a good argument with not so nice words is always infinitely more useful.

These boards just lack proper arguments, that's all, no matter where you look and how nice post are.
But let's just waste some time with an essay about why people swear especially on the internet and in online games that get played by lots of kids. That is a mystery somehow. (not really)

From what I've seen from you, you are exactly why this post is useful. The irony is just that you don't get it.

Your point is lacking nuance, which might be easier to get behind for you, but ultimately comes short when applied in practice. You see, it is nice and well for you that you can properly filter these threads. Good job! Though if you had grasped the meaning of my thread, you would have understood that my point is about having to filter threads in the first place.

Let me explain with an analogy:

Even if David by Michelangelo was covered in mud and dirt, I would still be able see that it is one frickin great sculpture. That  doesn't take away that I have to look past the dirt in the first place. As Michelangelo, I would want people to see the beauty of my sculpture without any noise hindering a clear view. That being said a bit a of dirt on the sculpture can give it a much more life like appearance and is in the end a positive thing.

That is exactly what use of swearing is about. Swearing is dirt, it either clouds your point or enhances it if used properly. 

The thing in an online environment is that you have hundreds of these sculptures next to each other and the viewers usually are not as invested in looking behind the dirt. 

Don't just place the entire choice on the reader when the writer clearly has power to give certain impressions. That aspect is essential for a lot of fields where you work with humans and I shouldn't need to point that out.

Stop feeding me moralistic BS. You are wasting your time, especially with those ridiculous comparisons. lul

> Don't just place the entire choice on the reader

But the entire choice is on the reader, how they want to read and react to something.

If you think you can get a bunch of gamers to act nice and talk like businessmen, then good luck with that. it doesn't change anything. Also not everyone likes fake positivity. Some people see through it quickly and are annoyed by it.

I was in the process of writing yet another iteration of how to best explain my point to you, but then I realised that I'd rather like to end this discussion on a positive note.

So here goes nothing:
